entry.et: Middle English, from Anglo-French, from Latin opinion-, opinio, from opinari

def.dt: :a view, judgment, or appraisal formed in the mind about a particular matter
:belief stronger than impression and less strong than positive knowledge
:a formal expression of judgment or advice by an expert
:the formal expression (as by a judge, court, or referee) of the legal reasons and principles upon which a legal decision is based

entry.pt: opinion view belief conviction persuasion sentiment mean a judgment one holds as true. opinion implies a conclusion thought out yet open to dispute each expert seemed to have a different opinion. view suggests a subjective opinion very assertive in stating his views. belief implies often deliberate acceptance and intellectual assent a firm belief in her party's platform. conviction applies to a firmly and seriously held belief the conviction that animal life is as sacred as human. persuasion suggests a belief grounded on assurance (as by evidence) of its truth was of the persuasion that everything changes. sentiment suggests a settled opinion reflective of one's feelings her feminist sentiments are well-known.
